1125129001507356673.text: Let's start focusing on the good bits of each of these efforts -- Hyperledger(s), Ethereum(s), Cordas..anything in open source -- and how we can persist the good bits and prune the less than good bits. It's open source, after all.

1125129000412745728.text: I can scoff at why so many organizations are taking up BaaS products like IBM Blockchain. I can say they don't get it and will have to rip and replace these consortium extranets soon. But I can't say it isn't happening. That would a lie..at least if I said it.

1125128999456399360.text: What's more telling is how, afaik, 0 clients have asked for the ordering service to use anything other than the Kafka plug. Kinda suggests that these clients really just wanted a shared database with a blockchain logo and weren't too concerned about one company controlling truth.

1125128998344900608.text: And saying that Fabric is based on Kafka is leaving out a lot of crucial context. The ordering service was originally built with simple Kafka just to stay focused on making the consensus layer pluggable. So if you want another consensus algo there, even pow, you can do it.

1125128997489336320.text: But saying that it is a fraud in it's claims of uptake (albeit by the kinds of old guard enterprises that usually buy stuff from the likes of IBM) is very much not what I'm hearing from..everyone I know on all sides.

1125128861077864448.text: I'm in the Ethereum camp these days, because of my need for a common frame of reference for applications I want to build. (Come to #etherealnyc on the 10th to hear more about that.) And I enjoy nothing more than calling bullshit on enterprise blockchain they way it's promoted.

1125128859953901570.text: Too bad we can't just call BaaS'es based on Fabric "shared data services". Fabric has terrific ACL and data/logic segregation support (not as good as Corda on the latter), and comparing TPS is just a dumb way to compare any distributed system.

1125128858703941632.text: I'll work out a set of considered issues, but bottom line: Fabric is getting used...a lot, and while it might not be a blockchain (who cares, really...it's an overused term), it does have attributes -- some unique -- that make it useful, depending on context.

1125128857756020736.text: But there are some things here I can't support without laying down my merit badge for "pig-headedness in pursuit of truth even when it doesn't suit me."

1122851216667697152.text: True story: Met with the heads of a major bank's IT Dept. I asked where was the need for enterprise blockchain in their project. They said, "There really isn't any, but we've been needing this upgrade for 15 years, and the boss will fund it if we call it blockchain."

1122851221713358851.text: The tech that will liberate all these business systems from this balkanized slag heap of incompatibility while preventing vendor lock in and ensuring confidentiality and true security is on its way. Just wish we had all the talent currently feeding that horse working on this.

1122851220496973824.text: When clients ask for a faster horse, we should hear "faster" and invent the car. IBM delivers a slightly faster horse. And I was part of making that happen. I'm working hard now to set it right...

1122851219175874560.text: I tell my old colleagues at IBM that it's time to build cross ledger parameter passing so that we can go from extranets to the real stateful Internet, and they say, "John, we are so busy building what the clients want..we just don't have time."

1122851217967857664.text: All this is adorable, and it doesn't really hurt anybody, but it annoys me, because it distracts from real projects that really do need blockchain, and it distracts from building the kind of tech that would truly advance what we can do.

1122827576353882112.text: But, the herd needed hype to get the money flowing to projects that were long overdue for a face lift. Like when your house needs paint, it helps to have someone sell you on an amazing new paint technology.

1122827575238234112.text: There are some great projects in here, and it would be a terrific, satisfying article from my pov, if we just replaced the word blockchain with "shared data services". All of these cases are really just improvements on old gear and old mental models.

1117741547158740992.text: ...them back in time.  So FanClub doesn't just give fans a way to fund a budding athlete or performer. It makes them a part owner in the rising star's "fanchise".

1117741545963307010.text: Also, the club can act as a franchise, receiving certain agreed-upon cashflows coming from, say, ad revenue from YouTube videos. Members can pay into the club more than their seat dues to cover something the celeb needs, and franchise revenues may (though not guaranteed) pay...

1117741545170591745.text: The value of all seats depends on the popularity of the celeb but also what the celeb is doing to make being in this small group of fans special. (Like monthly video conferences) But because of the cohort system, they only need to focus effort on their top 10 members in tier 1.

1117741544344305664.text: If the celeb starts to become famous, presumably the value of a seat in their club will go up. As there are only 1610 seats total forever, the price of each seat will go up. Existing members get 50% off the market price of a seat in their cohort. Or they can sell their seat.

1117741543580950528.text: Dues flow up from a cohort through the seat that organizes them (who gets a percentage) and ultimately to the fanchise warchest. Every year, any unspent funds are donated to the celeb's designated charity. Each club also funds global operations, such as onboarding support.

1117741542628823040.text: ...than seat 25, if the member in seat 1 of tier 2 is organizing better special events and delivering more overall value for their cohort than the member in seat 2 of tier 2.

1117741541680926720.text: That seat "owns" the dues from the seats below. So each member has a lot of incentive to bring in new members and not only keep the value of the club high but also the relative value of being in their cohort in the club high. (So you could be in seat 5 on tier 3 and pay more...

1117741540946980864.text: Each of the tier 1 seats can bring in ten more seats, each of these tier 2 seats can bring in 5 more, and each of these can bring in 2 more...and that's it. No more seats, ever. And every year, each member must pay dues at rates set by the seat in the tier above...

1117741540066168833.text: If, for example, a promising baseball player needs special coaching, the player can select "onboard new vendor" and have the service reach out to the coach and run the onboarding process. The club can then approve the appropriation, and that vendor is now accessible to all clubs.

1117741539160203264.text: And can only be spent through the club smart contract that restricts spending to approved vendors (who must be onboarded in order to accept payment via the smart contract). This prevents the athlete or performer or club member from misappropriating funds...

1069313031086268421.text: One other thing: it's essential that the notion of "excommunication" be emphasized.  Meaning, that System A will excommunicate System B if the branches of the trie that all entangled Systems expect to correspond to the restraining protocol don't pass hash function.

1069246393573871616.text: For avoidance of doubt, Party 2 controls System B, not Party 1.

1069239815542136833.text: Perhaps it is impossible to implement a subset of shared software objects such that, without knowing all elements of the total remote system, can verifiably prevent the unobserved objects from performing unsanctioned operations.

1069238163170840576.text: 15. final. I'm pretty sure I'm missing lots of devils in the details (so please, would be grateful for thoughtful replies along this thread to help me find the gaps).

1069238162495557632.text: 14. More extensibly, this kind of verified Entanglement might be used perhaps for things like system orchestration where different parties control different parts of a system. Future electrical grid SCADA systems come to mind.

1069238161279197184.text: 13. The notion here is a regime that says Entangled Systems trust a shared protocol to provide a kind of "restraining bolt" (nod to Star Wars) whose presence is verified before joint events can occur (initiation, copy, decryption, message passing).

1069238160612315136.text: 12. e) System A and B re-encrypt or verifiably delete System A data at the conclusion of the permitted operations.

1069238159874117635.text: 11. d) Protocol 'watchdogs' System B during the execution of the permitted operations (say for example, machine learning model generation on U) and ensures that System A data is not copied during process or used by non-sanctioned local operations.

1069238159198863360.text: 10. c) If a, b pass, receive System A's Part of a shared encryption scheme required to operate on System A's data locally in System B. The scheme is implemented in such a way that the received Part can't be used in subsequent operations without obtaining a new part from System A.

1069238158485794816.text: 9. b) check that System B is running on a High-Security-Module (HSM) and is compliant with other security measures, per original agreement with Party 1. If fail, delete System A from System B and send error.

1069238157722509312.text: 8. In this embodiment, the protocol will perform several operations: a) check that System B's state is unchanged from previous verification, and if fail, send error and delete all data provided by System A.

1069238156959121410.text: 7. System A and B send messages to each other at appropriate events to ensure that neither has changed its state and tampered with the implementation of the protocol. Let's call this "Entanglement" just for fun.

1069238156241833985.text: 6. This should be done in such a way that compliance is the only thing a remote system can learn about a local System, so that the internal functions of each Party can remain private.

1069238155365228544.text: 5. Both Systems A and B implement a common protocol and agree to share a trie of hashes that represent the world state of their respective systems, so that protocol compliance can be confirmed by each System observing specific hash markers in the remote System's trie.

1069238154547343363.text: 4. Party A can't be sure that Party B isn't a bad actor willing to surreptitiously copy System A data while performing the agreed-upon operations. Normally the risk of data appropriation would be too high, but...

1069238153779777537.text: 3. System B needs to perform a series of operations on a corpus U that joins data from System A and B in a way that requires all data to reside locally in System B. Parties A and B agree that only these operations are allowed. Party A permits no other use of System A data.

1069238152919945216.text: 2. Party 1 wants to share data from its System A with remote Party 2 and a System B, which it controls locally. Recent example: Facebook sharing data with Cambridge Analytica. (Simplified...could be n systems.)
